title: Aritz Gorostiza
text:
EU: Doktoretzako ikaslea Malagako Unibertsitatean
EN: PhD student in the University of Malaga
ES: Estudiante de Doctorando en la Universidad de Málaga

Ph.D. candidate in the Interuniversity Ph.D. Program in Communication at the Universities of Málaga, Huelva, Seville, and Cádiz, specializing in the field of Communication. Currently employed as a Predoctoral Fellow (FPU) in the Department of Communication and Advertising at the University of Málaga. Holds degrees in Political Science and Public Administration, as well as a Master’s in Strategic Thinking and Global Security from the University of Granada. Has undertaken research stays at the University of Bologna, Sofia University, and the University of Coimbra. Research interests primarily revolve around data mining, data center construction, and data analysis, with a focus on digital media and social networks. Main research efforts are dedicated to exploring the dynamics of influence among digital media, interest groups, and European construction.

title: La utilización del doble eje Y
text: Hola este es el primer post de prueba

title: Social Media and Data adquisition: Forget the APIs
text:
The use of twitter analisys has become immposiblle for the researchers.

Aunque pueda parecer un titular un poco agresivo, las API son fundamentales para los diferentes servicios de internet para no realentizar las interfaces de las páginas webs, estas se están volviendo en un negocio, no una forma de protección de las e3mpresas que gestionan las paáginas.

Además noe stamos hablando del uso de las APIs con pretensiones comerciales, aunque lo fueran. La información que el usuario ve en cualquiera de las redes sociales que se encuetra es una informaciuón pública, no tiene un caracter


La imposibilidad de trackear a lo alrgo del tiempo las estrategias comunicativas de los usuarios como la imposibilida de obstener información de forma constante.
La verificaciónd e los usuarios y el coste que trajo consigo también es y ha sido un tema de conflicto entre los diferentes usuarios.
Esto lleva a los investigadores sociales, y concretamente a aquellos que se dedican al análsis de las relaciones públicas a tener que desistir a utilizar twitter como medio importante de análsis, no porque no sea relevante, sino que porque les es imposible realizar análsis sistematicos a lo alrgo del tiempo.

Esto se debe a diferentes limitaciones impuestas por parte de Elon Muskl ty su nueva políutica tras la adquisición de twitter, que pone precio e incluso limita el número de tweets mensuales que los usuarios se pueden descargar para el anáisis.
Aunque todavia existan diferentes métodos para descargar tweets mediante la API (Application Programming Interface), estos quedan limitados a la imposibilidad de poder realizar aálsis sistematicos a lo largo del tiempo.
Actualmente las tarifas para poder descargar twitts se quedan de la suiguiente forma:
Otra de las politicas mas relevantes de twitter ha sido la monitización de los canales. Es decir, dependiendo de diversas variables no establecidas pero que tienen que ver con el engachment, el usuario puede obtener una reconpensa economica siempre y cuando esté pagando la verificación.

Las tarifas anteriores VS las tarifas actuales
Hasta estos dias la utilización de las APIs no venia determinada por el dinero que se pagaban por ellas, sino que para pasar de una básica a un grado mayor se debia de justificar porque se necesitaba. Incluso existia una API para investigadores, unlimited que se podían hacer descargas masivas de usuarios.
sin querer entrar en el palo para los community managers y atomatización de twitts, que
Actualimente, con la cuenta básica, se pueden descargar 1500 tweets mensuales o se puedes escribir 1500 tweets, y la máxima se encuentra en 500$ mensuales y la descarga de un millon de tweets.
Es decir, se suprime la posibilidad de descargas ilimitadas de tweets, muy valida para los investigadores y las nuevas tñécnvias de analissi de discursos
La guerra de twitter contra la adquisición de datos por parte de de investigadores y usuarios se ha extendido con la entrada de Elon Musk. Anteriormente las diferentes tarifas muchísimo más bajas para la utilización de la API hacian viables múltiples investigaciones y análsis de datos,

No es la única plataforma que lo hace, hay que tener en consideración que muchos de los usuarios
NUevas herramientas:
Python:
Snscrape
R:

TwitterR


Esto ha traido varias quejas:


Los usuarios tenderán a twitterar más, siendo los usuarios más comerciales, aumentando el spam con pretensiones económicas, desdibujando el caracter de plaza pública que habia adquirido el

title: Rvest package fof Web Scraping
text:
The first thing we have to know is that the web sraping is a automatization of the webpages publiclky avaible information. There is a several legislations about this tecnique, like the GDPR in Europe, in wich is delimeted for the Personal data or Personally Identifiablke Information (PII).
Anayways, apart from the legal cuestion, it is impiortant to know that webscraping is a new technique that relantizes the servers of the companies if we do it very agressivly, at the same time,

API


Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Nam suscipit est nec dui eleifend, at dictum elit ullamcorper. Aliquam feugiat dictum bibendum. Praesent fermentum laoreet quam, cursus volutpat odio dapibus in. Fusce luctus porttitor vehicula. Donec ac tortor nisi. Donec at lectus tortor. Morbi tempor, nibh non euismod viverra, metus arcu aliquet elit, sed fringilla urna leo vel purus.


This is inline code plus a small code chunk.

library(tidyverse)

ggplot(mpg) +
  geom_jitter(aes(cty, hwy), size = 4, alpha = 0.5) 








Transforming OLS estimatesMaximizing likelihood




Code
preds_lm %>% 
  ggplot(aes(body_mass_g, bill_length_mm, col = correct)) +
  geom_jitter(size = 4, alpha = 0.6) +
  facet_wrap(vars(species)) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c('grey60', thematic::okabe_ito(3)[3])) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(3000, 6000, 1000)) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 12) +
  theme(
    legend.position = 'top', 
    panel.background = element_rect(color = 'black'),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  ) +
  labs(
    x = 'Body mass (in g)',
    y = 'Bill length (in mm)'
  )









Code
glm.mod <- glm(sex ~ body_mass_g + bill_length_mm + species, family = binomial, data = dat)

preds <- dat %>% 
  mutate(
    prob.fit = glm.mod$fitted.values,
    prediction = if_else(prob.fit > 0.5, 'male', 'female'),
    correct = if_else(sex == prediction, 'correct', 'incorrect')
  )


preds %>% 
  ggplot(aes(body_mass_g, bill_length_mm, col = correct)) +
  geom_jitter(size = 4, alpha = 0.6) +
  facet_wrap(vars(species)) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(3000, 6000, 1000)) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c('grey60', thematic::okabe_ito(3)[3])) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 10) +
  theme(
    legend.position = 'top', 
    panel.background = element_rect(color = 'black'),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  ) +
  labs(
    x = 'Body mass (in g)',
    y = 'Bill length (in mm)'
  )










\[
\int_0^1 f(x) \ dx
\]








geom_density(
  mapping = NULL,
  data = NULL,
  stat = "density",
  position = "identity",
  ...,
  na.rm = FALSE,
  orientation = NA,
  show.legend = NA,
  inherit.aes = TRUE,
  outline.type = "upper"
)


stat_density(
  mapping = NULL,
  data = NULL,
  geom = "area",
  position = "stack",
  ...,
  bw = "nrd0",
  adjust = 1,
  kernel = "gaussian",
  n = 512,
  trim = FALSE,
  na.rm = FALSE,
  orientation = NA,
  show.legend = NA,
  inherit.aes = TRUE
)







ggplot(data = gapminder::gapminder, mapping = aes(x = lifeExp, fill = continent)) +
  stat_density(position = "identity", alpha = 0.5)




Bla bla bla. This is a caption in the margin. Super cool isn’t it?

title: Rvest package fof Web Scraping
text:
First steps
The rvest package have his own website and is avaiable the full documentation in the CRAN repository. Is a very easy package to use and to deal with, in wich the principal focus is in the html structure and there csss, tags or Xpaths between others. Lets try to do this easy tutorial with a naiz.eus webpage and the news that are avaiable.

title: Rvest package fof Web Scraping
text:
1 - Install the library
Like always, we need install the pacakge.

install.packages("rvest")

The following package(s) will be installed:
- rvest [1.0.3]
These packages will be installed into "~/MEGAsync/Proyectos/Blog_1/renv/library/R-4.1/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu".

# Installing packages --------------------------------------------------------
- Installing rvest ...                          OK [linked from cache]
Successfully installed 1 package in 4.5 milliseconds.


Once the package is installed, we need “call” the package to use their functions.

library(rvest)
library(tidyverse)

title: Rvest package fof Web Scraping
text:
2 - Read the page
First of all we need to read the page in pur local machine, is for this that we need to use read_html() function to save the html structure in the variable.

News_paper <- read_html("https://www.naiz.eus/")

print(News_paper)

{html_document}
<html lang="eu" xml:lang="eu">
[1] <head>\n<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8 ...
[2] <body>\n<div data-controller="cookies" data-cookies-content-value="<h2 ...

title: Rvest package fof Web Scraping
section: 3 - Find the CSS and Extract it
text:
3 - Find the CSS and Extract it
Like we see, we have the newspaper html structure in our variable. Once this is donne, we need to extract the css responsabile for the titles of the newspaper. For this task we can do it manually, clicking in the right button on the mouse and selecting the “inspect” option we can find manually the common css for all the titles of the articles.
 We can see that the common class or css por the articles is article, but if we move the mouse on the articles, we will see that the css us for all the article, no only the title. This way we need to split the article class to see how it the article divided in different classes to see what css is the correct one.
 Like we see, the css “article__title” is our appropiate css we need to use to extract the information. But before this, we need to ensure that we are scraping all th
Other way to do this more easy, is to install add ons we can use for this task (I use SelectorHub for Firefox and Selectorgadget for chrome navigator). This way we can select easier the css we want to dowload. In our case is

preds <- dat %>%

    correct = if_else(sex == prediction, 'correct', 'incorrect')
  )

  geom_jitter(size = 4, alpha = 0.6) +
  facet_wrap(vars(species)) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(3000, 6000, 1000)) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c('grey60', thematic::okabe_ito(3)[3])) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 10) +

title: Rvest package fof Web Scraping
text:
3 - Find the CSS
Like we see, we have the newspaper html structure in our variable. Once this is donne, we need to extract the css responsabile for the titles of the newspaper. For this task we can do it manually, clicking in the right button on the mouse and selecting the “inspect” option we can find manually the common css for all the titles of the articles.
 We can see that the common class or css por the articles is article, but if we move the mouse on the articles, we will see that the css us for all the article, no only the title. This way we need to split the article class to see how it the article divided in different classes to see what css is the correct one.
 Like we see, the css “article__title” is our appropiate css we need to use to extract the title of the article.
Other way to do this more easy, is to install add ons we can use for this task (I use SelectorHub for Firefox and Selectorgadget for chrome navigator). This way we can select easier the css we want to dowload. In our case is

title: Rvest package fof Web Scraping
text:
4 - Extract the titles
First of all we have to ensure that our css is apropuiate. For this lets try first to extract the first title. For this, first we have to stablish the csss like a node in wich we want extract and then extract the text of the node we determinate.

News_paper_title <- News_paper %>% html_node(".article__title") %>% html_text()
print(News_paper_title)

[1] "\n      Un avión militar ruso con 65 presos a bordo, derribado por un misil ucraniano\n      \n    "


We can see the the first title of the webpage, lets see if how we can get the second one.

News_paper_title_second <- News_paper %>% html_node(".article__title:nth-child(2)") %>% html_text()
print(News_paper_title)

[1] "\n      Un avión militar ruso con 65 presos a bordo, derribado por un misil ucraniano\n      \n    "


We can access to the “childs” of the css this way.
Now, we want all the titles toguether in one variable. Lets try to find trought the SelectorGadget in google chrome. For this goal we need to find apropiate css selecting with the add on. Once we see all the titles selected, we can try if all is correct with the selected css.


News_paper_titles <- News_paper %>% html_nodes(".article__title a") %>% html_text()
News_paper_titles

[42] "\n        Getariatik mundura: Cristobal Balenciaga\n        \n"

[44] "\n        Zetaren Bideko hirietan zehar\n        \n"                                                                  
[45] "\n        Urederra, harribitxi urdin turkesa, Urbasa mendilerroan\n        \n"                                        
[46] "\n        Palermo, Siziliaren sintesia\n        \n"                                                                   
[47] "\n        Zineman euskarak ez du ia tokirik, %2,48 Hego Euskal Herrian\n        \n"                                   


Now we can use one of multiples packages avaible to clean the text, but to do it simple, we can do it ease witn the function gsub()-

News_paper_titles <- gsub("\n        \n|\n        ","",News_paper_titles)
News_paper_titles

 [1] "Un avión militar ruso con 65 presos a bordo, derribado por un misil ucraniano"                  
 [2] "«Europar Parlamentuan ‘autodefentsa’ deitzen diote Israelen genozidioari»"

3 - Tabsets

Transforming OLS estimatesMaximizing likelihood




Code
preds_lm %>% 
  ggplot(aes(body_mass_g, bill_length_mm, col = correct)) +
  geom_jitter(size = 4, alpha = 0.6) +
  facet_wrap(vars(species)) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c('grey60', thematic::okabe_ito(3)[3])) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(3000, 6000, 1000)) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 12) +
  theme(
    legend.position = 'top', 
    panel.background = element_rect(color = 'black'),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  ) +
  labs(
    x = 'Body mass (in g)',
    y = 'Bill length (in mm)'
  )









Code
glm.mod <- glm(sex ~ body_mass_g + bill_length_mm + species, family = binomial, data = dat)

preds <- dat %>% 
  mutate(
    prob.fit = glm.mod$fitted.values,
    prediction = if_else(prob.fit > 0.5, 'male', 'female'),
    correct = if_else(sex == prediction, 'correct', 'incorrect')
  )


preds %>% 
  ggplot(aes(body_mass_g, bill_length_mm, col = correct)) +
  geom_jitter(size = 4, alpha = 0.6) +
  facet_wrap(vars(species)) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(3000, 6000, 1000)) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c('grey60', thematic::okabe_ito(3)[3])) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 10) +
  theme(
    legend.position = 'top', 
    panel.background = element_rect(color = 'black'),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  ) +
  labs(
    x = 'Body mass (in g)',
    y = 'Bill length (in mm)'
  )
